child.geography: Spoken from the Banks and Torres islands south to Efate, and on all the islands in between.

child.pub-comments: “Pawley's arguments for this subgroup, on re-examination, are promising but not convincing. This area includes some of the most conservative languages in North and Central Vanuatu (NCV), and much of their similarity appears to be due to common retention rather than innovation. […] With the much more complete data now available, it appears that these innovations by no means define a coherent North Vanuatu area” (Clark 1985:211). “The languages of Santo probably comprise a genetic unit. The remaining North Vanuatu (NV) languages seem to be unified mainly by retentions rather than innovations” (Clark 1985:221).

“Several lexical innovations suggest that all the languages of “Espiritu Santo (groups 5, 6 and 7) constitute a single subgroup” (Clark 1985:212). “Here and elsewhere, languages of north Malekula share various features with those of Santo. Although it cannot by demonstrated as yet by means of phonological history, as would be ideal, the sporadic distribution of these agreements suggests diffusion rather than common ancestry” (Clark 1985:213).

child.pub-comments: “...there seems to be no evidence which would place the East Santo languages (group 7) outside the North and Central Vanuatu (NCV) group. They positively reflect not only a number of Proto-NCV (PNCV), but also several assignable to late stages or subgroups within NCV […]. The apparently aberrant position of these languages thus appears to result from a high rate of lexical innovation, parallel to the high phonological innovativeness of these languages, especially Sakao” (Clark 1985:213).

child.pub-comments: “Two grammatical innovations may be restricted to the north-eastern area, groups 1-3 (Torres, Banks, Aoba-Maewo-Raga). […] Evidence of shared innovations in the north-eastern area is thus rather weak. In view of the stronger case for a Santo subgroup, [...] it may be possible to explain these few features as North Vanuatu innovations which subsequently been lost in Santo. The main basis for the perceived close relation of groups 1-3 is clearly a shared conservatism” (Clark 1985:212).

child.geography: Spoken on Aoba and Maewo islands, as well as the north of the Pentecost island.

child.pub-comments: “The islands from Malekula and Pentecost south to Efate will be referred to here as Central Vanuatu (CV). […] 15 of the 22 local groups are in the central area, 10 of them in Malekula alone” (Clark 1985:213). “...there remains a certain amount of evidence to support the inclusion of at least a large majority of the CV languages in a single subgroup” (Clark 1985:214).

This Ambrym subgroup [amby] is not to be confused with [ambr] of the same name, from the Tryon 1973 analysis. They share two similar languages, North Ambrym and Dakaka, but otherwise include different languages. Tryon's Ambrym [ambr] includes North Ambrym, Dakaka, Southeast Ambrym, Paama and Sa, which have been split into three groups in the present analysis.

child.pub-comments: “As with the East Santo languages (see section 6.4), there is no evidence that the 'Malekula Interior Group' of Tryon's classification should be separated from the rest of North and Central Vanuatu (NCV). The languages of this group share many of the innovations of Central Vanuatu […]. Their unity within themselves is less clear than in the case of the East Santo cluster. However, there is a group of lexical innovations which are restricted to Malekula and which occur most frequently in groups 10, 11, 12, 15 and 17. […] This group, which we might term 'West Malekulan', differs from Tryon's 'Malekula Interior' in that it also includes Southwest Bay and Malfaxal of group 17. More importantly, it is seen not as a high-level separate group, but as a focus of series of innovations” (Clark 1985:217-18).

child.geography: Spoken along the southwestern coast of Malekula.

child.pub-comments: “Although none of these innovations in itself is particularly good evidence the conjunction of the three does tend to add some support to the hypothesis of an Epi-Efate subgroup” (Clark 1985:216). “Epi and Efate may constitutea subgroup, but the evidence is not very strong” (Clark 1985:221).

child.geography: Spoken on Efate Island and the Shepherd Islands.

child.publications: Clark, Ross. 1985. Languages of North and Central Vanuatu: Groups, Chains, Clusters and Waves, Austronesian Linguistics at the 15th Pacific Science Congress, vol. C-88, 199-236. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858833298

Clark, Ross. 1985. Languages of North and Central Vanuatu: Groups, Chains, Clusters and Waves, Austronesian Linguistics at the 15th Pacific Science Congress, vol. C-88, 199-236. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858833298

child.pub-comments: “Pawley mentions three lexical items which in Codrington's lists seem to be uniquely shared by the Epi and Efate languages: rarua 'canoe', goroi 'woman', and tamoli 'man'. These now appear to have been a philological will-o'-the-wisp. They are North Efate words, but do not appear in any of Tryon's 15 Epi dialects. Probably they are contaminations in Codrington's sources, originating from the now extinct Livara dialect of North Efate which was spoken at the south-east end of Epi (Ray 1926:198)” (Clark 1985:216).
child.publications: Clark, Ross. 1985. Languages of North and Central Vanuatu: Groups, Chains, Clusters and Waves, Austronesian Linguistics at the 15th Pacific Science Congress, vol. C-88, 199-236. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858833298

child.pub-comments: “Within Central Vanuatu, the major split appears to be between Epi-Efate and the rest. Group 19 (Paama and South-East Ambrym) appears somewhat uncertain in its affinities between these two” (Clark 1985:221).
child.geography: Spoken in southeast Ambrym, as well as Paama and Lopevi islands.
